Appearance is foggy yellow. Aroma is of wheat, oranges, and lemons. Flavor is crisp and refreshing with a slight lemon note. Palate has a touch of alcohol and bitterness. I dont care for this style but for a German Wheat beer, its not bad.

Foamy head and yellowy for a hefe-weizen.  Great flavor though; very fruity and hoppy for this style.  I taste a bit of spices, maybe even some corriander and vanilla.  It tastes like a mix between a wheat beer and a belgian double.  It gets a little watery at the end but is a very nice brew.

Brass hue, average rocky white head, good lacing. Murky light to medium body. Very complex aroma for a weizen, hints of pine, grapefruit, horse blanket, banana, and clove. Very floral. Moderate acidic and bitter flavor, hop bite, mild spice, and a hint of vanilla. The taste explodes on the palate. Excellent. Fruity long finish. Do they make a average wheat beer? All 3 I've tasted have been excellent and each unique. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

This is pretty good. Some ester bananna action with a freshly mowed hayfield aroma. The appearance is a bit weak with a strange oily yellow color. The flavor is a hit with ample carbonation and a mellow wheatyness. Not much in the way of head
Light wheat beer with very little floral overtones and though nice flavor, it's not a beer I will try again.  Disappointing.
Cloudy amber,short lived white head.Light cirus spicy yeast nose.Cloying yeasty flavor. I never learn...I just dislike the yeasty german wheat style beers.
Aroma is slightly metallic, with a certain bitterness.  No head at all.  Fine and minimal carbonation.  Flavor is wheaty and one dimensional.  Clean crisp finish.  A pretty average wheat.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2004 ReRate:   This tasting many, many months later bought for the delicious notes of clove, banana, a note of coriander, and cardamom. Excellent beer!  This is a very original Hefe-Werizen. This beer oddly surprised me, it reminded me of a Grozet Lagered Celtic Ale. This Edel-Weisse is heavily hopped with a zesty, spicy, bitter finish. This is a beer that absolutely deserves a try.

Aroma is interesting, yeasty, with some lactic(milk) aromas as well as a hint of hop spice; slightly lighter in appearance than the "regular" Schneider weiss, but darker than most hefeweizens. Flavor is spicy and spruce like, all most like Orval with bannana in the place of the brett character. Really drys out the back of the throat, scratching it all most. Still, I find this beer unique, and it makes a nice (ocasional) alternative to regular hefe-weiss...

Aroma is dominated by wheat malts and banana.  Also noticeable is a yeasty smell.  Colour is hazy and light yellow, very straw like.  Head is huge, white and frothy with great lacing.  Starts off with strong banana flavour and then gets a dry hoppy taste before ending with a tangy sweet citrusy finish.  This beer reminds me of a mix between a Belgian strong and a wheat beer.  A nice balance relates to a nice and enjoyable beer.

Color a hazy light yellow-gold---frothy white head and thick honeycomb lace...Aroma lightly yeasty with signature wheat malt sweet & sour nose...Banana tones punctuate sweet malt front, with hop dryness and mild yeasty tang close in tow---carbonation in just enough quantity to add spritely touches.  Finish has ghostly lemon traces and is nicely dry. More than adequate body anchors brew that has substance, variety of flavor and texture, and fine balance.  This is a solid all-around performer.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 Mild banana malt aroma with large pure white head. Hazy due to bottle conditioned yeast aspect. Nice hop bite with a soft rounded middle and somewhat tart lemon notes. Long lingering finish. Excellent!
Pale yellow hazy color.  Sweet cereal that has been left in the bowl too long nose.  Bitting bitterness and subtle wheat textures.  Fizzy and dry.  Lively and tangy.

Light gold color. Medium head. Aroma is malty with a hint of lemon. Medium bodied wheat. Hoppier than normal for a wheat beer. Crisp and clean, dry and light and refreshing. Very drinkable. Touch of lemony flavor. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

Crisp, clean and refreshing. Smells of fresh picked flowers, the Edel-Weisse is an obvious addition to their weisse recipe. Nice clean gold coloration with a mild head retention. Hops are obvious. Nice and balanced. A clean finish.
The head was much larger than some others have described - I don't know what makes the difference.  There is a definite hop taste, with just a bit too bitter a finish.  Otherwise, very good.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2004 The color is flaxen with yeasty cloudiness and a thin, white head. The nose is of roasted grains and a slight hint of lemony hops. The palate accentuates the lemony character but retains some light maltiness. The finish is quick and lightly astringent. 

Organic Version: The nose is malty and toasty with an interesting starchy note like stewed rutabaga or mango. Perfumed notes of clover honey. The plate is yeasty, bready and honeyed. Toward the finish, light lemon zest appears. The finish is rich and creamy.

Much hoppier than any other german wheat I've had. The hops are present in the aroma, as well as the flavor. A bit more strength than most other hefe-weizens too. Definitely a hoppier example of the style, but the fruitiness is still present. A little of the classic banana/clove but with some citrus tones. Almost no head. Tettnanger hops would be my guess.

This beer poured a pale gold color and formed a nice foamy white head that retained and left circular lace. A good deal of carbonation was present and probably helped account for the nice head. Some sediment was present as well. It had an aroma of citrus, clove and bannana. The flavor was of citrus and grain. The body was very light and the finish slightly tart. Not bad, but there are better ones out there.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2003  

Quick fizzy dusty white foam.  Unrefined aroma mostly showing lemon zest, clove, coconut, vanilla, pepper, light phenols, and leafy hops.  Lacking estery qualities, which I love, complexity,  and sharpness.  Watery palate; smooth carbonation level.  Predictable flavors of light citric notes, vanilla, bread, cilantro, and very sloppy malts and cardboard.  Zero depth while displaying only the slightest sign of leafy hop.  Too much yeastinesss and acidity interferes.  Finishes with abundant dry mint, clove, artificial sweetener and a touch of phenol.  Surprisingly disppointing, and only slightly better than a good American Wheat.  Note:  Extremely fresh bottle.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 5, 2004 Terribly drinkable.  Nose of bananas cloves and fruit.  Oh so smooth a sweet.  Very nice, bubblegum and cloves all the way, finishes dry and crisp.  A nicely balanced beer, very quaffable.  Very different, unique yeast flavor.  I really enjoy this...How come all the low marks?
Not bad. Dry and crisp with big wheat flavor.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2005 mmmm yummy. like a normal hefe on steroids. very intense wheaty, salty, meaty flavours (corned beef?) and a really nice long bready vanilla and peach juice finish. complex perfumey aromas of baked apple, cloves, banana - the usual stuff except more powerful. good one rer8: tasted quite belgian to me last night - I wonder if JPDIPSO is right? rer8 again: amazingly fresh zingy wheaty flavour, with more tinned peaches turning up than banana/clove etc rer8: flavours are good, as listed above, only the texture is too watery. could be more carbonated and fluffy then i might like it better. i must admit to a bit of boredom with hefes over the last cuppler years.
Opaque. More so than Guinness, although certainly not the same color. A great deal of head. Probably one of the best Bavarian wheats Ive had, almost a Perfect Abstraction of the Hefeweizen.
UPDATED: JUL 11, 2007 Another fine product from a small outfit in Bavaria that knows how to do things right. I return to this one often.
It smells like cake batter. Definate citrus character, and a bit of banana. Seems to be firmer bodied than most wheats.

Foam poured out before I had a chance to pour it.  When I got it into the glass, I was left with a cloudy yellow body with a big white head.  Aroma is wheat, clove, banana and lemon.  Flavor is milder than Id expect, almost nothing up front, with wheat and citric showing up around mid-tongue and staying into the swallow.

Dissapointing head - too thin and sudsy, although it is large on pouring. Body is good - light in colour but very opaque. Nice, friuty, spicy, hoppy aroma.  Great clovey bitterness, banana, citris and slightly alcoholic finish. Pretty enjoyable wheat. Extra alcohol is noticeable and interesting.
Virtually identical to the Weisse, but lacking a bit of the over-the-top esther character I liked so much.
I dont think this one is as good as the Schneider weiss but its still got the powerful bubblegummy esters. The lemony character is subdued as is the malt.
Nice fruity aroma. This bit of extra alcohol warms you nicely and blends great with complex set of flavours. Pale in look, orangey-lemon, some head was present. Great beer!

Enjoyable German Wheat. Banana in both the aroma and flavour. A bit citric and orangy, also a bit clovy. Dry, yeasty and a bit fizzy. Alcohol was slightly noticable at the end. Yeah, yeah, like it, like it. Not as good as id hoped.

Wheat, malt aroma, cloudy golden, large off white head, lots of bubbles. Light wheat flavour, terrific bitterness. Bounces off the tongue, loads of carbonation. Even though its stronger, it seems a lighter version of the Schneider Weisse? A very good Wheat Beer!
Slightly softer and more malty than the regular weisse.  Still quite a nice clovey hefe.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2003 Had this one last night. Great wheat beer. Not as good as the other Schneider wheats, though. Golden brown in color and semi clear until the yeast is mixed then it is a cloudy brownish blond. Slight fruit or floral taste to it. Not as spicy as expected. Overall great beer. Recommended to wheat beer fans.
a very well made wheat beer.  Wonderful head and nice cloudy appearance.  Bonus points for the extra alcohol kick.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2007 Cloudyish with an aroma that is wheat dominant, but also showcases esters, cloves, and banana. The flavor is a tasty wheatiness with some banana and cloves to round it out. A stronger wheat profile than most wheat beers, which should give wheat beer fans their fix.

golden pear color, or murky chicken noodle soup, about as clear as a table leg. i think my mustache will be the first filtration system this beverage has encountered. all that flotsam in there looks like a mobile depicting how your septic system works, theres enough particulate grain and yeast to bake a small muffin. head was pretty but shortlived as an arizona snowfall. cinnamon applesauce aroma, pear. spicy and easy palette, not especially sweet. makes you want to try it for breakfast, as the bavarians do. unlike them, i dont feel any subsequent urge to conquer europe, but merely to relax and relish a quenching, well crafted product.

Hints of bananas, cloves, and apples in the aroma. Nice cloudy amber appearance. Clean tasting with a nice bit of tartness. A little less wheat malt presence than expected. Overall fairly good, if a touch on the thin side.

hazy golden color, thick fluffy white head.
hasa lot of intereesting flavors cloves,  oranges, light hops and a yeasty element.
more complex than most weiss beers.
Noble wheat, smoother than most hefes, a step above the normal weisse
dry cloudy with the yeast more mild than not

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2004 Pours a cloudy yellow, huge thick foamy white head, leaves a clingy lace in the glass, aroma of wheat, bananas and spices. Flavors of wheat, banana-clove yeasty flavor. Nice body clean and crisp, carbonated mouthfeel, very refreshing another one of my favorites.

Just an overall superbly crafted beer. Lemony banana sour wheat in the nose perfectly mirrored in the flavor. What I really liked is the cloudy, fairly hefty body and the tinge of a brown to the golden color. Tingly, and just very good.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Poured a nice golden color. Just the color that looks refreshing on a hot day.Nice fluffy white head. This is a great summer time pleaser. Clean, crisp and even a little dry.

Hazy, golden, small head.  Slight and mysterious smell, wheatiness and perhaps some sweetness in the aroma.  A little bit of woodiness compliments the dry wheat flavor quite well and it goes down smooth.  Yeastiness abounds.  Nice!

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2005 Deep hazy golden color.  Wheat malt and citrus aroma.  Very effervescent.   Surprisingly strong wheat-malt and malt flavors, mixed with some tangy citrusiness, spices and light hops.  Heavier body than your typical hefe.  Finish is clean, dry, refreshing, and malty.  For an authentic German Hefe Weizen, this is certainly a bigger and more complex beer than most of its kind that Ive sampled.  Quite a good beer.

Typical citrus nose with a fluffy head, and a light bronze color. Initially very fizzy but not in a bad way. The sour flavor relents to reveal a very nice hop aroma and a well balanced maltiness. Not the best wheat but very nice.
Cloudy, quite wheaty, somewhat metallic taste.  However, rather good.
Theres something about this one that I dont like that much, maybe its a bit too sour. This is the first Schneider brew that was a little disappointing to me.
copper color, medium head.  normal wheat taste, more citrus finish than typical.  it was just O>K>
This has to be the best damn german beer i have had.  It kinda tastes like hefe but stronger.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 What a great special Weiss.  The mix of a hefe with the yeast of a belgium strong.  An acquired taste but the yeast it is with this one.   Ok another rerate ala leap year. I hope Weissbierbrauerei G. Schneider & Sohn does not take too much of a hit, as they die have 4 in my top ten and one has already left the scene to the near 4+ range. I will state that the first time I had this one, I literary went back out and bought the remaining stock - so it was 18 bottle, Someone else and I had purchased the other two bottles from the one case that the store had received. Once again time is not necessarily a friend to this one. A fresh bottle was much different. I am now stuck in a spot, do I leave my rate of yore, or do I rate what others have likely had. I think I will go with middle ground. All I will say is old bottles of this suck. I hope you find new bottles when you find this. This does not age nearly as well as Aventinus. I hope to find fresh bottles again.
A good but not great wheat, had a lot of fruitiness to it some hints of bannana that I realy liked. It was a little too vinegary and sour, but not overwhelmingly so. Hides the 6.2% prety well.

Didnt know what to expect from this brewer.  Typical German wheat appearance---nice thick head, hazy golden color---though much more yeast particles floating around, not to mention the mud at the bottom of the bottle.  Not alot of aroma though, which was a bit disappointing.  The taste is grainy, with a hint of banana and spice but again not as much as I would expect, considering this IS a German wheat.  The taste soured quickly to me, though not in the cheap beer way, but sour nonetheless.  My mouth is still sour, in fact.  So, it may be true to the style, but it doesnt finish as well as others Ive tried.  Too watery and lemony and/or acidic for my liking.  That taste just didnt blend well with all the yeast in the brew.  It isnt bad, just not my favorite German wheat.

Hazy copper color with an average sized white head that diminishes quickly.  Aromas of yeast over a backdrop of noble hops.  Flavors are interesting. Light malt and yeast up front with a sweet, fruity middle and a bitter and lemon/citric acid finish.  Body is average.  A good Weisse, but not their best product.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2004 Head is initially average sized, fizzy, off-white, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (cookie, toasted grain), moderately hoppy (flowers), moderately yeasty (cobwebs, mold), with strong notes of banana and clove. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, heavily bitter, slightly husky. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. Newer bottle with the organic crap all over it.  Seems that organic beers are often grainy, and only sometimes great (my experience with Pinkus-Mueller has been the same...when theyre on, theyre great, otherwise, not very good at all).  This is a grainy example.
Definitely my favorite wheat beer. Nice and fruity/yeasty aroma, cloudy/gold hue and a refreshing fruit feel. This is ony of my favorite early summer beers.
UPDATED: APR 11, 2003 RE-RATE: Another excellent beer from Schneider. This beer is right up there with the Weihenstephaner weisses and Ayinger weisses.

A good wheat beer; clean and crisp. I think this is great at room temperature, but then again I drink all my beers at room temperature.  Well not all of them, if I think that a beer may actually make me puke (like Keystone Light) it needs to be ice cold.  But then again I dont drink beer like that unless I need to rate a popular beer to set some people straight.  Or unle...wait this is about Schneider Weisse not about crap.  This is great beer!  Have one now.
Very nice hefe. Spicy in the right places and yeasty to all ends. Watch that gas build up in your intestines after downing all that yeast. My wife wont let me sleep in the bed if I drink this beer.
Good Beer.
A very good Weiss. Well balanced and tasty with a suprising punch.
Great body & citrus/clove flavor.  Rather yeasty, but still good.  Ligh brown/slightly opaque appearance.

Exceptional. Huge creamy mouthfeel with a sharp crispness. Loads of cloves and yeasty notes alongside a perfect citric balance. A near perfect Americanized HefeWeizen that is drinkable and dangerous at 6.2%ABV. Nicely made.

Dull orange-brown and cloudy, with a striking cloves, yeast aroma.  Smooth and slightly tangy, hops are evident underneath this beers lemon effervesence. A bit fruity and malty as well, however this beers main detractor is its yeast aftertaste, which almost completely saps the enjoyment out of the first 3/4 of the gulp.
Orange color with a light white head. Biting citric taste. Interesting metallic, bitter aftertaste. While this is not offensive it isnt really great.
An excellent wheat. Hearty and cheawy!
What the style should taste like. Foamy, fresh, and flavorful. Wow.

Really good hefeweizen. To my taste, this and Weihenstephan seem to represent the ideal type for this style. Mildly spicy flavor, carbonation thats in control, a hint of yeast taste, beautiful cloudiness. No complaints.
Hazy yellow, some floating particles, short lived head(could have been the glass) some wheat, some cloves...a bit sour. A bit disappointing.
Bit dry,  but nice.

Great flavor in this Weiss beer.
Nice malt and light hop flavor blend nearly perfectly.
Not much experience in this style, so I dont want to say much.  I thought this beer was quite good.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2004 As the beer withdraws from the captivity of the bottle it pours after decanting a nice chill hazed deep amber color with the head majestic as it sits atop the body, the texture creamy and the color a brilliant white, as it ever so slowly dissolves, the lace forms a silky curtain to seal off the glass. Nose is earthy, with lots of sweet malt, citrus crisp and clean to the senses; start is sweet and has a nice grain profile, the top middling in feel. Finish is forbearing in its acidity, the hops good-hearted in their spiciness, quite dry and somewhat sweet aftertaste, and a great beer that will be ever so welcome here in the desert when it hits the 110s just a few months from now.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 Cloudy amber.  Slightly melony, herbal, hay-like hops on the nose with a big wheat body and a touch of alcohol.  Herbal flavour with light wheat.  Clean.  Finishes a little on the dry side.  A straightforward beer, but good when fresh.
